Description: Massachusetts-based financial services company State Street Corporation entered into a deferred prosecution agreement and agreed to pay a $32.3 million criminal penalty to resolve charges that it engaged in a scheme to defraud a number of the bank's clients by secretly applying commissions to billions of dollars of securities trades.

Company: State Street Bank and Trust Company
Description: State Street Bank and Trust Company agreed to pay $382.4 million in a global settlement for misleading mutual funds and other custody clients by applying hidden markups to foreign currency exchange trades.

Company: State Street Bank and Trust Company
Description: State Street Bank and Trust Company agreed to pay more than $310 million to settle allegations of misleading its investors about their exposure to subprime investments while selectively disclosing more complete information to specific investors.

Company: State Street Bank and Trust Company
Description: State Street Bank and Trust Company agreed to pay $12 million to settle charges that it conducted a pay-to-play scheme through its then-senior vice president and a hired lobbyist to win contracts to service Ohio pension funds.

Company: State Street Bank and Trust Company
Description: State Street agreed to pay more than $35 million to settle allegations that it fraudulently charged secret markups for transition management services and separately omitted material information about the operation of its platform for trading U.S. Treasury securities.

Agency: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs

Description: The case involved allegations that State Street inflated its share price by overcharging clients on foreign exchange services and falsely representing that its investments in mortgage-backed securities were safe. Suits were brought on behalf of State Street employees with company stock in their retirement accounts and on behalf of investors. The settlement listed here relates to the employees; the company separately agreed to pay its shareholders $60 million.
Private Litigation Case Title: Kenney v. State Street Corporation et al

Company: State Street Bank And Trust Co.
Private Litigation Case Title: In re State Street Bank And Trust Co. ERISA Litigation

Description: The ERISA portion of the settlement was allocated $60 million of the $300 million total.
Private Litigation Case Title: Arkansas Teacher Retirement System v. State Street Corporation et al

Description: State Street Bank agreed to pay $11.7 million to the Washington State Investment Board to settle a contract dispute over the pricing of foreign exchange transactions executed between 1997 and 2007 while State Street was the custody bank for the WSIB.

State Street Bank agreed to pay approximately $310 million in restitution to investors and a $10 million penalty to the Commonwealth as part of a settlement of allegations it misled fund investors about the riskiness of their investments and did not disclose information necessary for investors to decide on remaining in collective trust funds it managed. The settlement was also announced by the SEC; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-state-street-bank-and-trust-company-1

Company: State Street Bank and Trust Co.
Description: State Street agreed to return $75 million in disgorgement and pay $500,000 to the Commonwealth in settlement of allegations it misrepresented exchange rates for foreign exchange transactions so that clients did not receive the favorable exchange rates they expected. This was part of a larger $382 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-state-street-bank-and-trust-company

Company: State Street Bank and Trust Company
Description: State Street Bank and Trust Company agreed to pay over $88 million to settle allegations of overcharging mutual funds and other registered investment company clients for expenses related to the firm's custody of client assets.

State Street agreed to pay restitution expected to exceed $48 million and a $5.5 million civil penalty in settlement of allegations it overcharged clients for use of the SWIFT system, charging markups for sending messages when the system was expected to be paid for on an out-of-pocket basis. A related settlement with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission resolved federal allegations.

State Street agreed to pay a $1,456,174 administrative penalty and disgorge to the Commonwealth $3,543,826 of its fees, profits and commissions, in settlement of allegations that when acting as Investment Manger for Carina CDO Ltd. it made misleading omissions in connection with the offer, sale or purchase of securities, which operated as a fraud or deceit.

Company: State Street Bank and Trust Company
Agency: New Hampshire Bureau of Securities Regulation

Description: NASD fined State Street Global Markets, LLC $1.4 million for violations relating to the reporting of corporate and municipal bond trades. State Street Global, a subsidiary of Boston-based State Street Corporation, was cited for failing to report thousands of corporate bond trades to NASD's Trade Reporting and Compliance Engine (TRACE) and hundreds of municipal bond trades to the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board (MSRB) over a 17-month period.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Company: State Street Research Investment Services, Inc.
Description: NASD fined State Street Research Investment Services, Inc. (SSR) $1 million for failing to prevent market timing of State Street Research mutual funds due to its inadequate supervisory systems. SSR also agreed to pay more than $500,000 in restitution to the individual State Street Research mutual funds to compensate the for losses attributed to the market timing activity.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: Massachusetts-based global financial services company State Street Corporation entered into a deferred prosecution agreement and agreed to pay a $115 million criminal penalty to resolve charges that it engaged in a scheme to defraud a number of the bank's clients by secretly overcharging for expenses related to the bank's custody of client assets.
